properties.title: À la Marguerite
properties.description: A high-end, modern bistro from the team behind Les Fines Gueueles.
properties.reservations: book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Beef Club
properties.description: Upstairs: a white-tiled resto featuring meat from butcher Yves-Marie Le Bourdonnec. Downstairs: drinks by the Experimental Cocktail Club crew.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Café des Abattoirs
properties.description: A meat-centric spot from the Rostang sisters – daughters of Michelin-starred chef Michel and the sixth generation of restaurateurs in their family.
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Camélia
properties.description: Camélia is the second restaurant by chef Thierry Marx inside the Mandarin Oriental. Slightly more casual than his flagship Sur Mesur.
properties.hours: Open every day, breakfast, lunch, and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Fish Club
properties.description: This outpost from the ECC crew (just down the street from its meat-centric sister spot Beef Club), is a sleek fish joint with a South American twist. Crab cakes, ceviches, tinned fish, oysters and other seafood small plates are accompanied by a tight list of pisco based cocktails and interesting French beers.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance
properties.style: South american, oysters & fruit des mer

properties.title: Izakaya Issé
properties.description: Issé has changed formats a few times over the years, and now it’s a “bistro à sake”, offering a menu of izakaya — small plates — for grazing while sipping something from the serious selection of sake.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Juveniles
properties.description: What used to be a friendly wine bar run by the inimitable Tim Johnston is now a friendly wine bistro run by Tim’s daughter Margaux and her boyfriend Romain. The inspired cooking from Romain (formerly at Le Comptoir and La Régalade Saint-Honore) goes well beyond the satisfying sausage & mash of the old carte and Margaux’s service and wine selections make this a place where you’ll want to become a regular. The shelves of wine near the entrance contain many lovely bottles that can be purchased to go.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Kei
properties.description: After working for Ducasse for seven years, Kei Kobayashi has opened an eponymous restaurant in the old Gerard Besson space, offering four or five courses at lunch (38/48€) and six or eight (75/95€) at dinner.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Kunitoraya
properties.description: A favorite address for udon and rice bowls. Reservations are not accepted, so be prepared to queue unless you go early.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Kunitoraya 2
properties.description: Slurp your udon in style at this new branch of the rue Sainte Anne classic, housed in a renovated brasserie. Menus range from 18€ at lunch to a hefty 70€ at night.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: L’Ecume Saint-Honoré
properties.description: The sight and smell of this sparkling poissonnerie will transport you from Paris to the seashore. Take something home or eat sûr place. Open from 11 a.m.-7 p.m. Tuesday through Thursday, and until 10 p.m. on Friday and Saturday. Included in our list of Five Great Places for Oysters.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: La Régalade – Saint Honoré
properties.description: This second location of La Régalade has been full since chef Bruno Doucet opened the doors in spring of 2010. The formula (terrine + 3 classic courses for a prix fixe) has since been replicated at a third location in the 9th. Is it less special now that it’s a franchise? Some think so (see below), but it remains a good bet in central Paris, especially on Mondays.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: La Dame de Pic
properties.description: This is the Paris outpost from Anne-Sophie Pic, named in 2011 as “the world’s best female chef” for her three-star restaurant in Valence. Here, and working with Philippe Bousseton, the nose for perfumer Takasago, Pic has created three menus based upon fragrance profiles. Menus at 49€ (lunch), 79€, 100€ and 120€.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: La Tour de Montlhéry – Chez Denise
properties.description: The market at Les Halles is long gone, but its legacy is still in evidence at Chez Denise, an old-school, shoulder-to-shoulder, red-checked tablecloth classic. Open ’til the wee hours.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually O.K.

properties.title: Le Garde Robe
properties.description: Natural wine, snacks to soak it up, rowdy crowds and dancing bartenders. One of the original natural wine hangouts in Paris. Bottles also available for purchase to go.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Le Meurice
properties.description: This Michelin 3-star was helmed by Yannick Alleno until he moved on in 2013 after opening his locavore bistro Terroir Parisien. Alain Ducasse took the reigns in September 2013.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Le Petit Vendôme
properties.description: If you really want to lunch as the locals do, visit this old fashioned Auvergnate casse-croute.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday, Closed Monday dinner, Closed Tuesday dinner, Closed Wednesday dinner, Closed Saturday
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Le Rubis
properties.description: With its zinc bar, hearty home cooking, and colorful local clientele, this beloved wine bar (and its Turkish toilet) seems impervious to change. Meals are served only at lunch; the rest of the day you can stop for a glass of Morgon or Brouilly and a snack.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Les Bistronomes
properties.description: The menu here appears classic enough (barring a salmon tataki), but the presentations are full of surprises.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday lunch and all day Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually O.K.

properties.title: Les Fines Gueules
properties.description: On a lovely corner near the Place des Victoires, Les Fines Gueules adheres to the good-ingredients-prepared-simple formula. Warning: recent reader comments have raised concerns about the service.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK
properties.address_clean: 43 rue Croix des Petits Champs, Paris 75001

properties.title: Lobster Bar
properties.description: The latest and perhaps most fashionable evidence of Paris’ continuing obsession with American sandwiches, Lobster Bar is the project of Swiss screenwriter Mathieu Mercier. He offers a smallish lobster roll with fries and salad for 26€, a small selection of spreadable seafood starters, and an even smaller list of wines. The decor is intriguing, with underwater fresco by Swedish illustrator Vår, but the ambiance is undermined by the room’s oppressive humidity. Read more in our First Look at Lobster Bar.
properties.reservations: Not accepted

properties.title: Macéo
properties.description: The more elegant sibling of Willi’s Wine Bar, with a dedicated tasting menu for vegetarians in addition to their carnivorous fare.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Naritake
properties.description: A dive of a ramen shop, where the signature is a fat-enriched broth.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Saturday; closed Sunday
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Olio Pane Vino
properties.description: Round up a group and head to Olio Pane Vino for handmade pasta dishes and Francesco’s unmistakably Italian hospitality.
properties.hours: Lunch, Monday-Saturday; Dinner, Thursday-Saturday; closed Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Pinxo
properties.description: Sharing is encouraged at this contemporary, convivial, Basque-style tapas restaurant from Alain Dutournier.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Friday; open Saturday for dinner only
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Pirouette
properties.description: Chef Tomy Gousset passed through the kitchens of Le Meurice and Daniel Bouloud (NYC) before opening this stunning new restaurant in the underserved district just north of Les Halles. Serious technique is brought to bear on beautiful veggies and offal alike. The consistently delicious dishes, the polished room and the very good wine list all add up to something that’s much greater than the bargain prices should allow. There’s a prix fixe at lunch for only 15€, and diners can go à la carte at lunch or dinner for 36€. Recommended.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Racines 2
properties.description: Now open: Racines, version 2.0, featuring the same product-driven cooking as the original, in a Philippe Starck-designed space.
properties.hours: Open for lunch & dinner Monday-Friday plus Saturday dinner; closed Saturday lunch & all day Sunday
properties.reservations: book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Spring Restaurant
properties.description: American chef Daniel Rose offers a menu that changes with the seasons, and his whim. A very tough reservation.
properties.hours: Lunch, Wednesday-Friday; Dinner, Tuesday-Saturday; Closed Sunday and Monday.
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance (lunch reservations can be made<a href="http

properties.title: Sur Mesure
properties.description: The man behind the curtain in this white-on-white, Kubrick-esque space in the new Mandarin Oriental is molecular master Thierry Marx.
properties.address: 251 rue Saint-Honoré (in the Mandarin Oriental hotel), 75001
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Verjus Restaurant
properties.description: The couple behind Hidden Kitchen now has a very public showcase for the bold, refined, contemporary American cooking that earned them a loyal following over the years. For a less expensive, small-plates redux, visit the wine bar downstairs.
properties.reservations: Reservations accepted for first seating only, later tables available to walk-ins; book weeks in advance.

properties.title: Verjus Bar à Vin
properties.description: The small plates have big flavors at this tiny, no-reservations wine bar near the Palais Royal. Favorite bites include the fried chicken, the celery root dumplings with dan dan sauce, and any of their pasta dishes. Word to the wise: the small and beautiful space gets very busy on weeknights, and with a mostly English-speaking crowd. For something more formal and with more seating, book the restaurant upstairs.
properties.hours: Dinner Monday-Friday, 6pm-11pm; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: not accepted

properties.title: Willi’s Wine Bar
properties.description: Mark Williamson’s landmark wine bar turned 30 in 2010. It’s packed with suits from the Bourse at lunch, and an Anglo-heavy crowd in the evenings.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday, Open Monday-Saturday for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Yam’Tcha
properties.description: Universally praised Franco-Chinois fare from Adeline Grattard, and all but impossible to book.
properties.hours: Closed all day Sunday and Monday, plus Tuesday lunch
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: Aux Lyonnais
properties.description: The Ducasse group runs this longstanding address for Lyon-style cooking.
properties.hours: Lunch, Tuesday-Friday; open Saturday for dinner only; closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Chez Georges
properties.description: A popular, old school bistro serving classics like frisée au lardons, jambon persillée, escargot, and tarte tatin.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Friday; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Coinstot Vino
properties.description: Guillaume Dupré runs this wine bar in the passage des Panoramas, serving a range of small plates for snackers, a few hot items for the hungry, and vins natures for the thirsty.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Drouant
properties.description: Facing a very pretty square, Drouant has been around since 1880. Now run by Antoine Westermann, the menu offers elegantly updated classics with an emphasis on seafood.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Entre Deux Rives
properties.description: A slick little dinette offering pho, bo bun and other Vietnamese favorites.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Fée Nature
properties.description: Everything is organic at this Sentier lunch spot and tea salon.
properties.hours: Monday-Friday, noon-4 p.m.; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: not accepted

properties.title: Floyd’s Bar & Grill
properties.description: At first glance, Floyd’s appears to simply be a bar with craft cocktails and snacks. Keep wandering past the kitchen though and you’ll find the back half of the building is a modern Gallic update on the classic American steakhouse from the team behind Pink Flamingo. The menu features fusion items like fried rabbit & waffles or buffalo frog’s legs, plus Kansas City style ribs. Sunday brunch is an Anglo-style roast with Yorkshire pudding and veg for 18€.
properties.reservations: Walk-Ins Welcome

properties.title: Frenchie
properties.description: Gregory Marchand’s contemporary market cooking has landed Frenchie on every must-go list, making reservations all but impossible. Three courses, 48€.
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance.

properties.title: Frenchie Bar à Vins
properties.description: If you want a taste of Gregory Marchand’s cooking without the challenge of scoring a reservation at Frenchie, this is where to go.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Frenchie To Go
properties.description: Just down the street from the impossible to get into Frenchie, you can complete the Gregory Marchand hat trick at the latest outpost from the renowned Frenchie chef. The Anglo-inspired eatery features excellent Reubens, flavorful fish and chips, sweet treats like cheesecake and doughnuts, housemade ginger beer, pickles & maple smoked bacon, and one of the best beer lists we’ve seen in Paris. Unless you like cold meat and a greasy bag, we suggest eating on-site at the 15 seat space rather than taking the goods to go as suggested.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Goust
properties.description: Enrico Bernardo, who won the World’s Best Sommelier title at the age of 27, has opened a new restaurant that some critics are praising as the best opening of Spring 2013. The lunch menu at 35€ and dinner dégustation menus at 75 and 130€ feature wines selected by Bernardo paired with creations from chef José Manuel Miguel.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday Lunch, Closed all day Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Grillé
properties.description: This might be the most pedigreed kebab you’ll ever eat: prepared by Le Chateaubriand alum Frédéric Peneau with meat from butcher Hugo Desnoyer, homemade spelt flatbread, and herbs from Annie Bertin. Veal, lamb, or pork (depending on the day), the kebabs are served with your choice of white sauce (fromage frais and horseradish) or green (a barely spicy, green tomato and pepper sauce). A vegetarian option beyond the fries will be available soon. There aren’t any seats on-site, or even in the immediate vicinity, so be prepared to eat it on the go.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday and Sunday; Open Monday-Friday for lunch
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Gyoza Bar
properties.description: A Japanese dumpling bar, from the Passage 53 team.
properties.reservations: not accepted

properties.title: Hokkaido
properties.description: A busy noodle bar near rue Sainte Anne, serving gyoza and ramen. CLOSED FOR RENOVATION IN JULY AND AUGUST 2014.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Il Campionissimo
properties.description: This popular, prize-winning pizzeria has moved to a larger, pop-art space, with room for the whole family.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Friday; Saturday, dinner only; closed Sunday
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Bistro Volnay
properties.description: Heavy silver, plush carpeting, and swanky art deco decor give the Volnay plenty of adult sophistication.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Legrand Filles et Fils
properties.description: Lovely Legrand occupies an enviable place off the galerie Vivienne. Mainly a shop, there is a room with a bar and a few tables for a drink and a snack on the spot.

properties.title: Les Jalles
properties.description: Delphine Alcover and Magali Marian of Bistro Volnay have opened this chic, open-every-day bistro, serving breakfast, lunch and dinner, and drinks in the bar upstairs.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday; Open Monday-Saturday for breakfast, lunch, and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Liza
properties.description: Lebanese goes chic (et un peu cher) at Liza.
properties.hours: Monday-Friday, lunch and dinner; Saturday, dinner only; Sunday, brunch only.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Passage 53
properties.description: An absolute favorite
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Racines
properties.description: Founding chef Pierre Jancou has moved on, but the roots remain. New chef Renaud Marcille is bringing a touch of elegance to the product-driven, market cooking, served, as always, with natural wine, inside the city’s oldest covered passage.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Rice & Fish
properties.description: An inexpensive pair of Japanese restaurants (run by an American chef) along rue Grenata. 16 rue Greneta continues to feature innovative maki and sushi, while 22,the space that formerly contained Rice & Beans (R.I.P.), has been transformed into a Japanese grill.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday; Open Monday-Wednesday only for lunch; Open Thursday-Saturday for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Saturne
properties.description: Ingredient fetishists will appreciate Sven Chartier’s reverence for product, and devotees of natural wines will love Ewen Lemoigne’s list.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Terroir Parisien at the Palais Brongniart
properties.description: This new location of Yannick Alleno’s popular bistro is one of our favorite new openings of 2013, featuring pedigreed local ingredients and updated classic recipes from the region around Paris. This location at the Bourse boasts a rillettes bar sells terrines and pâtés to go.
properties.hours: Closed Sundays; open Monday-Saturday for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Al Taglio
properties.description: It’s pizza by the kilo at this (vaguely) Roman-style spot. Bright lights, high stools and cheap wine by the carafe. Locations in Oberkampf and the upper Marais.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Bob’s Kitchen
properties.description: Lunch at Bob’s might include a smoothie green with wheatgrass, a plate-sized pancake, a spicy veggie burger, or a colorful curry. All natural, all organic.
properties.hours: Open every day for breakfast and lunch
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Breizh Café
properties.description: An absolute favorite
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Café des Musées
properties.description: There’s a lot to like about this bustling corner bistro: The cooking is honest, the location is easy, and it’s open every day.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Café Pinson
properties.description: Fashionable health food freaks (and the two actual vegans in Paris) can get their fix at this casual California inspired hangout.
properties.hours: Open Monday-Saturday for breakfast and lunch; Closed Sunday
properties.reservations: Recommended for brunch

properties.title: Candelaria
properties.description: With its bright, bare-bones kitchen, crowded counter, communal table, and addictive salsas — all mercifully un-Frenchified — this upper Marais spot has officially changed the game, and people are lining up for tacos and agua fresca. Go through the unmarked door next to the stove and you’ll find a serious bar, staffed by Experimental Cocktail Club grads.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Chez Omar
properties.description: Go early, or be prepared to queue up with the fashionable masses at this perennially popular address for couscous.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Cuisine de Bar
properties.description: This lunch spot is run by the Poilâne people, and features tartines – open faced sandwiches, hot and cold – on their famous bread. Locations in the 6th and 3rd.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Dessance
properties.description: Life is short. Eat dessert first. And second. And for every other course at this desserts-focused restaurant where the small plate sweets are nuanced and occasionally savory.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Glou
properties.description: Pedigreed and organic ingredients rule the menu, and pretty waitresses run the loft-like, two-level, room. Open every day.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Grazie
properties.description: Piping hot pies with fresh toppings, industrial loft décor, and cold cocktails from the full bar draw the branché masses to this pizza place between République and Bastille.
properties.transport: Saint Sebastien Froissart or Chemin Vert (8)
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Gyoza Bar 2
properties.description: A chic second location of the Japanese dumpling bar. Flavored angel food cake rolls from Patisserie Ciel complement the (otherwise) dumpling only menu.
properties.reservations: Walk-Ins Welcome

properties.title: Happy Nouilles
properties.description: Hand made Chinese noodles, at very happy prices.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Wednesday-Monday; closed Tuesday
properties.reservations: Not accepted

properties.title: La Briciola
properties.description: The pizzas are thin-crusted and fresh at this upper Marais spot.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: L’Ami Louis
properties.description: It’s possible that this legendary address serves the most famous — and expensive — roast chicken in the world. A roster of VIP regulars (hello, Bill Clinton) who make this a difficult reservation for us plebes.
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: Le Barav’
properties.description: This friendly upper Marais wine bar serves simple charcuterie, cheese, salads, and sandwiches to go along with 5€ glasses, or a bottle from their cave next door. In the summer, there’s a great terrace on the street.
properties.hours: Lunch, Monday-Friday; dinner, Tuesday-Saturday; closed Sunday
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Le Mary Celeste
properties.description: An absolute favorite
properties.hours: Open 6pm-2am Monday-Friday, open noon-2am on Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: Recommended for dinner via their <a href="http

properties.title: Les Enfants Rouges
properties.description: A perfect example of bistronomie from a young Japanese chef who trained under Yves Camborde right near the Marche des Enfants Rouges.
properties.hours: Closed Tuesday; open Monday and Wednesday-Sunday for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a few weeks in advance

properties.title: Nanashi
properties.description: Colorful, Japanese-inflected salads, soups, and small plates, as well as a decidedly non-Japanese coffee cream tart, courtesy of a Rose Bakery alum. Three locations, one on the rapidly changing rue du Paradis, the thoroughly bobofied upper Marais, and now in the Bonpoint boutique in the 6th.
properties.address: 6 rue de Tournon, 75006 (in the Bonpoint boutique)
properties.hours: Tuesday-Saturday, 10 a.m.-6 p.m.; closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Pink Flamingo
properties.description: “Pas comme les autres,” is the motto at kitschy cool Pink Flamingo Pizza. Take-out and delivery available at all locations.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Rose Bakery
properties.description: You’ll find colorful salads, Neal’s Yard cheeses, strong coffee, a stellar carrot cake, and other lunch/brunch fare at this super-bobo British bakery. Locations in the 9th and the 3rd.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Benoît
properties.description: Open since 1912, this picture-postcard Paris bistro is part of the Ducasse group.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Brasserie de l’Isle Saint Louis
properties.description: This classic brasserie has been in business since 1953, and is still run the same family.
properties.hours: Closed Wednesday; open all other days, noon-11pm
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Chez Marianne
properties.description: This mainstay of the Jewish quarter is popular for its platters of salads, breads, and lovely terrace, though many line up here for falafel, too.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK
properties.address_clean: 2 rue des Hospitaliéres St. Gervais, Paris 75004

properties.title: Claude Colliot
properties.description: This self-taught modernist chef’s signature dishes include an oyster sorbet, chicken cooked with licorice root, and a “larme” (tear) of chocolate.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Icho
properties.description: Take a seat at the counter of this slick little sushi bar and watch chef Aroun Tanovan turn out pristine sashimi, riotous rolls of pink and green, and salads of seaweed, ginger, and yuzu.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Isami
properties.description: Since 1992, chef Katsuo Nakamura has been impressing Parisians with formidable skill and quiet rigor at this tiny Ile Saint-Louis sushi bar.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Jaja
properties.description: From the team behind Glou comes Jaja, a contemporary bistro featuring top notch organic products, a serious wine list, airy urban decor, and…hot dogs. Open every day.
properties.transport: Hotel de Ville (1, 11) or Saint Paul (1)
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: L’Alimentari
properties.description: A minuscule trattoria in the heart of the Marais.
properties.hours: Lunch & dinner Tuesday-Saturday; closed Sunday & Monday
properties.reservations: book a few days in advance

properties.title: L’Ambroisie
properties.description: Everything at L’Ambroisie, from the Place des Vosges setting to the piles of caviar to the prices, could be described as aristocratic. A Michelin three-star.
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: L’As du Fallafel
properties.description: Cheap, messy and seemingly obligatory. The line-averse should probably avoid it on a Sunday afternoon.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Le Métropolitain
properties.description: Vintage Metro posters decorate the walls of this contemporary bistro, where a Top Chef finalist has taken over the stove.
properties.hours: Monday-Friday, noon-3pm and 7pm-midnight; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Le Sergent Recruteur
properties.description: Michel Bras’ protégé Antonin Bonnet has taken over the former tourist trap near Notre Dame and transformed the space into a sleeker, chicer dining experience. Diners fly blind sans menu but can expect high quality local products.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Maison David
properties.description: Squeeze into this tiny butcher shop for lunch and watch owner Michel Kalifa in action.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday and Monday; lunch other days, 1-3 p.m. Dinner available for private parties only.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Miznon
properties.description: Another pita place for the Marais–this annex of an Israeli chain has above average, far more creative offerings than your corner kebab stand. Notable options include grilled cauliflower, grilled sweet potato, and beef bourguignon.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday; Open Monday-Thursday and Sunday from 12pm-12am and Friday from 12-3pm
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Mon Vieil Ami
properties.description: A contemporary bistro on the Ile Saint-Louis from noted chef Antoine Westermann, where vegetables rule.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: 58 Qualité Street
properties.description: “Finger food for globe-trotters” from the team behind Itinéraires. The menu ranges from Indian spiced lentils to Italian bruschetta & polenta to Japanese rice balls to homemade ice creams. Part épicerie, part restaurant, part cave à vin, food is served continuously throughout the day. Sandwiches can eaten at the counter or packed to-go.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted
properties.style: Italian, French, Japanese, small plates & tapas

properties.title: Anahuacalli
properties.description: A well-regarded Mexican address in the 5th, serving specialties like huitlacoche quesadillas, tortilla soup, mole and tamales.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Aux Verres de Contact
properties.description: This casual bistro is an annex of the well-regarded Jadis, but the reviewers have found it to be a little lackluster.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Café de la Nouvelle Mairie
properties.description: This is a true café, open all day long starting at 8am. But it’s the natural wines and simple food that keep this place busy.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary
properties.style: Classic French, small plates and tapas
properties.address_clean: 19 rue des Fossés Saint Jacques, Paris 75005

properties.title: Christophe
properties.description: NOW CLOSED.

properties.title: Dans Les Landes
properties.description: A salade landaise served as a spring roll, mini croissants with truffles and ham, sardine rillettes, crisp polenta with smoked duck: this wine bar with a terrasse serves a lengthy list of creative tapas for gourmand grazing, plus well-priced wines. Note: Julien Duboué sold Dans les Landes in July 2014 to open a new place near the Bourse. We haven’t yet returned to try Dans les Landes under the new management.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Desvouges
properties.description: This neighborhood bistro, run by a former journalist who always dreamed of having a restaurant. Three courses, 26€.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday-Sunday, Closed Monday dinner, Closed Tuesday dinner
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK
properties.address_clean: 6 rue des Fossés Saint Marcel, Paris 75005

properties.title: Itinéraires
properties.description: In fall of 2011, Sarah and Sylvain Sendra (founders/sellers of Le Temps au Temps) changed the format of their popular modern bistro, reducing the number of seats by almost half, and offering dégustation menus (59€, 79€) at night.
properties.hours: Closed Monday lunch and all day Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: La Tour d’Argent
properties.description: Chef Laurent Delarbre has run the kitchen of this landmark since 2010, bringing modern sensibility to the menu while maintaining much of the restaurant’s classic repertoire, including the famous numbered ducklings.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Le Bistro des Gastronomes
properties.description: Everyone likes the razor clams and reasonable prices at this neighborhood restaurant, once unknown but lately much-vaunted. You can add chef Cédric Lefevre’s name to the bistronomical family tree: He has worked for both Thierry Breton and Christian Constant.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Le Porte-Pot
properties.description: An address for a decent glass of wine in the Latin Quarter, and bottles to go, too.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Le Pré Verre
properties.description: You’ll see ginger and lemongrass in the mix at this popular bistro. Note: The restaurant is under new management after the departure of the Delacourcelle brothers.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Ribouldingue
properties.description: Le Ribouldingue is not for the faint of heart, but for those who want to eat it. Heart, that is. And bones and liver and tongue and kidney.
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance
properties.address_clean: 10 rue St. Julien le Pauvre, Paris 75005

properties.title: Lengué
properties.description: An Izakaya joint, serving small plates, Japanese beer and cocktails, in the heart of the touristville.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Les Papilles
properties.description: Bring some friends to share in Bertrand Bluy’s family style dinner at this cave à manger. Still very well-priced at only 31€ for four courses, and with an excellent selection of bottles sold at caviste prices, either to-go or to open at the table for a modest corkage fee.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Les Pâtes Vivantes
properties.description: Hand-thrown noodles are stretched and cut before your eyes at this Chinese spot.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Sola
properties.description: A refined Franco-Japanese address from the owners of Youlin.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Terroir Parisien
properties.description: Yannick Alleno (formerly of Le Meurice) revives Parisian classics, with Ile de France ingredients, at this chic, airy bistro.
properties.hours: Open every day for breakfast, lunch, and dinner
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Allard
properties.description: The sepia-toned dining room at this historic bistro remains the same, but Alain Ducasse and protégé Laëtitia Rouabah have taken over the kitchen and the accompanying carte of classic Burgundian dishes. Reviews are mixed.
properties.hours: Open every day for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Bread & Roses
properties.description: An English-accented bakery, lunch spot and tea salon featuring fresh tarts (savory and sweet), sandwiches, and lively salads, plus flaky scones, serious cheesecake, and a few grocery items.

properties.title: Café Trama
properties.description: Well-prepared, simple, affordable food and all-natural wines served by a friendly team led by Marion Trama (of the prominent culinary family).
properties.hours: Closed Sunday and Monday; Open for lunch and dinner Tuesday-Saturday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Cosi
properties.description: The sandwiches at this shop — run by Juan Sanchez and Drew Harré of Fish — are made with a focaccia-like bread, right from the oven, with fresh fillings and plenty of vegetarian choices. Open every day.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Chez Marcel
properties.description: A new owner has resuscitated this old time bistro, serving updated Lyonnais classics.
properties.transport: Notre Dame des Champs (12) or Vavin (4)
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Friday; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: book a few days in advance

properties.title: Eggs & Co.
properties.description: Eggs rule the roost at this sunny spot in Saint-Germain, where brunch is not only for Sundays. Formerly known as Coco & Co.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Fish (La Boissonnerie)
properties.description: This popular restaurant and wine bar run by Drew Harre and Juan Sanchez is a sort of Anglo haven, excellent for a quick glass, a solo dinner at the bar, or for those times when you’re just tired of speaking French. Current chef Oliver Clarke is turning out some really solid food.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Fogón
properties.description: A popular, contemporary Spanish table.
properties.hours: Open for lunch and dinner Tuesday-Sunday, Closed Monday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: La Salle à Manger d’Hélène (Darroze)
properties.description: Hélène Darroze is one of only a handful women whose work has been consecrated by Michelin. Her cooking is strongly accented with southwestern flavors, here elevated to one-star levels in a modern, luxe dining room, as well as the less formal “salon,” where small plates are available.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Huitrerie Régis
properties.description: Régis’ fantastic oysters come from the Marenne-Oleron and are available for dégustation on the spot in the pale blue and white dining room, or to take home. Included in our list of Five Great Places for Oysters.
properties.hours: Closed Monday; there’s also a lengthy annual summer closing
properties.reservations: Not accepted

properties.title: Josephine (Chez Dumonet)
properties.description: Bring your appetite, and wallet, to this perennial favorite for old fashioned favorites like boeuf bourgignon, duck confit and gigot d’agneau.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Friday; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a week or so in advance

properties.title: KGB (Kitchen Galerie Bis)
properties.description: KGB is the offshoot of fusion master William Ledeuil’s Kitchen Galerie, offering the same mash up of global flavors that made him famous, in small plate format and at lower prices.
properties.transport: St. Michel (4, RER B, C) or Odéon (4, 10)
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: L’Atelier Vivanda
properties.description: After opening his eponymous restaurant in 2011, Akrame Benallal is back with a second offering. This time it’s all about the meat, and his wallet-friendly prix-fixe at L’Atelier Vivanda includes a starter, a choice of meat (Black Angus beef, suckling lamb, Challans poultry), a side of potato (grilled, Dauphinois, galette) and a classic dessert for €35. Exceptional products like the 45-day côte de bœuf are available for those willing to pay a supplement.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: L’Avant Comptoir
properties.description: Crêpes up front and pork (Ibaïona) in the rear. It’s standing room only at Yves Camdeborde’s tapas and wine bar, a hit since it opened in fall of 2009. Go during the off hours or be prepared to be get to know the person next to you very, very well.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: L’Epi Dupin
properties.description: L’Epi Dupin has been attracting a mix of loyal locals and tourists since it opened in 1995.
properties.hours: Dinner, Monday-Friday; lunch, Tuesday-Friday; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually O.K.

properties.title: La Crèmerie
properties.description: Natural wines, great products, in an exquisite old space. Slightly draconian hours.
properties.hours: Their hours are complicated and seem to change a lot. Our latest understanding is as follows
properties.reservations: Accepted for dinner only. Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: La Rotonde
properties.description: A classic Montparnasse café and brasserie, serving standards like onion soup and steak tartare all day, along with oysters and other seafood in season.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Le 21
properties.description: Book in advance for a table in this discreet enclave in the 6th, where chef Paul Minchelli continues to cook some of the most delicate and exquisite seafood in town.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Tuesday-Saturday; closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: book a week or so in advance

properties.title: Le Chardenoux des Près
properties.description: A second outpost of Cyril Lignac’s Chardenoux. Prices are trés Saint-Germain.
properties.hours: Open every day, lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Le Comptoir du Relais
properties.description: Yves Camdeborde’s beloved bistro, once neo and now classic. Book months in advance for weeknight, no-choice dinner, or just queue up at lunch or weekends for the so-called “brasserie menu”.
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance for dinner weeknights; reservations not accepted for lunch and weekends

properties.title: Le Relais de l’Entrecôte
properties.description: At Le Relais de L’Entrecôte, the choices are steak or steak, and the supply of golden fries is unending. Which is how the line to be seated will seem unless you go early. Included in our list of Five Great Steak Frites in Paris. Three locations.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Le Timbre
properties.description: A loyal neighborhood clientele keeps the twenty-or-so seats filled at this tiny bistro, run by English chef-owner Chris Wright.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Little Breizh
properties.description: Hidden in plain sight on a street of tourist traps, this charming crêperie features organic ingredients, nutty galettes flecked with buckwheat, tender dessert crêpes, and sweet service. You can get out for under 20€, barring a cider bender.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Moustache
properties.description: This neighborhood restaurant on the south side of the Luxembourg gardens offers a mix of classic and contemporary French cooking with Asian accents.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday, Closed Monday, Closed Saturday lunch
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Pizza Chic
properties.description: Devotées love the artichoke pizza at this (very) sixth arrondissment address, which features a wood-burning oven, and contentious pricing.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Ralph’s
properties.description: Ralph Lauren brings the beef to Saint-Germain, along with clam chowder, cheesecake and other iconic American dishes.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Semilla
properties.description: Juan Sanchez and Drew Harré expand their empire (Fish, Cosi, La Dernière Goutte) with this contemporary bistro, offering market-driven plates in full or half size, in a renovated Saint Germain space with a gleaming open kitchen.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Toyo
properties.description: In this sleek little space, Toyomitsu Nakayama (the former personal chef to fashion designer Kenzo) plies his trade in an open kitchen.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Yen
properties.description: A well-regarded soba specialist in the sixth.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Saturday; closed Sunday
properties.reservations: book a few days in advance

properties.title: Ze Kitchen Galerie
properties.description: East meets west at William Ledeuil’s much-lauded Ze Kitchen Galerie.
properties.transport: Odéon (4, 10) or St. Michel (4, RER B, C)
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Alain Milliat
properties.description: Alain Milliat’s exquisite fruit juices, nectars, and conserves line the walls of this boutique-cum-restaurant, serving a no-choice menu at lunch and dinner, operating as a tea salon in the afternoons, and open for shopping all day.
properties.hours: Open 10am-10pm Tuesday-Saturday, and for lunch on Sunday; Closed Monday
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Auguste
properties.description: Gael Orieux’s menu at the polished and posh Auguste is all about seafood.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Bellota-Bellota
properties.description: The specialty here is Iberian ham. Take a bocadillo (sandwich) to go, or sit at the counter or communal table for a lunch, dinner, or snacks. Open all day.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Bistrot Belhara
properties.description: Picture perfect Parisian bistro with Basque-inflected food from Thierry Dufroux, who sharpened his teeth at Alain Ducasse, Bernard Loiseau, Michel Guérard, and Bistro Volnay. The restaurant can be reserved privately for large groups on Sundays and Mondays.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday and Monday; Open Tuesday-Saturday
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Café Constant
properties.description: Christian Constant is the unofficial mayor of rue St. Dominique. His casual, no-reservations café is open all day, starting at 8 in the morning.
properties.transport: Ècole Militaire (8) or Pont de l’Alma (RER C)
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Chez L’Ami Jean
properties.description: Brash and belly-filling, a meal at l’Ami Jean can be coma-inducing. Reserve in advance, and plan on walking home.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Coutume
properties.description: Part of the new wave of cafés, Coutume serves serious coffee drinks along with light & healthy lunch fare.
properties.reservations: Recommended for brunch

properties.title: FL
properties.description: Young chef Nicholas Valanchon is drawing attention for inventive cooking that’s grounded in the traditions of his native Picardy.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Gaya
properties.description: Pierre Gagnaire’s thoroughly modern seafood spot.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Garance
properties.description: Two Guillaumes (Guillaume Iskandar and Guillaume Muller) formerly of l’Arpège, have opened this much-praised modern bistro near the Esplanade des Invalides.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday and Sunday; Open Monday-Friday for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Jean-François Piège
properties.description: Above bustling Thoumieux, his brasserie gourmande, Jean-François Piège has opened an intimate 20-seat showcase for his creative, modern French cooking. Michelin awarded 2 stars within months of his opening.
properties.hours: Dinner only, Monday-Friday; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: L’Arpège
properties.description: Alain Passard spins turnips into gold at this vegecentric (but not vegetarian) three star restaurant.
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: L’Atelier Saint-Germain de Joël Robuchon
properties.description: The original L’Atelier, in what’s now a global empire. Known for a particular brand of relaxed fine dining, our contributors nonetheless voted it on to our list of Five Great Steak Frites in Paris. Note: Reservations are ONLY accepted for the first seatings of each service. Otherwise, it’s first-come-first-served.
properties.reservations: Reservations accepted ONLY for the 11

properties.title: La Ferme Saint-Simon
properties.description: A long-established restaurant near the Musée d’Orsay, has been redesigned and updated – both in the kitchen and the dining room – with pleasing results.
properties.hours: Open every day for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: La Fontaine de Mars
properties.description: The Obamas ate here! The Obamas ate here! This perpetual favorite, a mainstay on the crowded rue Saint-Dominique, offers classic cooking with a southwestern tilt. Open every day.
properties.transport: École Militaire (8) or Pont de l’Alma (RER C)
properties.hours: Open every day, lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: La Laiterie Sainte-Clotilde
properties.description: A down-to-earth bistro in a high rent neighborhood.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Saturday; closed Sunday
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: La Table d’Aki
properties.description: L’Ambroisie vet Akihiro Horikoshi does everything at this 16-seat jewel box in the 7th.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Tuesday-Saturday; closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Le Cinq Mars
properties.description: This perennially popular bistro serves classics like foie gras mi-cuit, steak tartare, and brandade de morue.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Saturday; closed Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Les Climats
properties.description: Worth a trip for the gorgeous terrace alone (at lunchtime only). The excellent all-Burgundy wine list and fresh, albeit somewhat under-seasoned, modern French dishes don’t hurt either. Note: the terrace is now closed at night due to noise complaints from grumpy neighbors, but is still open for lunch.
properties.transport: Rue du Bac (12), Solférino (12), Musée d’Orsay (RER C)
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Les Cocottes
properties.description: Though the breezy service and long counter are reminiscent of an American diner, they are not slinging hash at Christian Constant’s Les Cocottes. An easy, no-reservations choice in the shadow of the Eiffel Tower.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Les Fables de la Fontaine
properties.description: The specialty is seafood at this lovely rue St. Dominique address. Open every day.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Le Jules Verne
properties.description: Perched high in the Eiffel Tower, the restaurant was taken over by Ducasse, and his chef Pascal Féraud offers a menu of classics, befitting of the location (foie gras in many forms, escargots, tournedos de boeuf, Bresse chicken, savarin a l’Armagnac). One Michelin star.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Lily Wang
properties.description: The arrival of the bill may preclude any happy endings at this bordello-like Chinese address in the 7th.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Pottoka
properties.description: A tiny Basque joint from the duo behind Les Fables de la Fontaine.
properties.transport: École Militaire (8) or Pont de l’Alma (RER C)
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Restaurant David Toutain
properties.description: David Toutain is back. The much lauded chef, who brought acclaim to Agapé Substance before jumping ship back in December 2012, returned with his own place during the last days of 2013.  His meticulous and conceptual cooking highlights seasonal produce, with vegetables often playing the starring role. This is by no means a vegetarian restaurant, but Toutain’s ability to bring out the beauty in oft-ignored roots reminds us of his former boss Alain Passard. Tasting menus range from 42€ at lunch to 98€ for the most extensive menu (available at lunch or dinner). Wine pairings – thoughtfully done – are available for another 40-50€.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday and Sunday; Open Monday-Friday for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a few weeks in advance at reservation@davidtoutain.com

properties.title: Restaurant ES
properties.description: Simplicity reigns here, both in the stark whitewashed room and in the delicate flavors and beautiful presentations of the no-choice Japanese tasting menu. Chef Takayuki Honjo was formerly at L’Astrance, Noma, and and Mugaritz.
properties.hours: Open Tuesday-Saturday; Closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Thoumieux
properties.description: The brasserie reinvented, by Jean-François Piège.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Treize
properties.description: Southern hospitality, savory hand pies, salads and slices of layer cake from Laurel Sanderson (formerly at Sugarplum Cake shop). It’s part bistro, part bakery, and even part coffee shop, with beans from Coutume and 13 custom blended teas including a carrot cake rooibos.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday and Monday, open Tuesday-Saturday 10am-6pm
properties.reservations: Reservations not required

properties.title: Alain Ducasse at the Plaza Athénée
properties.description: Alain Ducasse’s flagship at the Plaza Athénée remains one of the bastions of French gastronomy. Since autumn 2014, the restaurant has reoriented its cuisine around fish, cereals and vegetables.
properties.hours: Dinner, Monday-Friday; lunch, Thursday-Friday; closed Saturday and Sunday.
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: Le Marché du Lucas
properties.description: A relaxed but still elegant alternative to Alain Senderens’ flagship table. Counter seating makes this one to consider for solo dining. Formerly known as “Bar Le Passage.”
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Caffè
properties.description: A see-and-be-seen Italian table from Thierry Costes and Thierry Burlot.
properties.transport: Saint Philip du Roule (9) or Franklin Roosevelt (1, 9)
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Charbon Rouge
properties.description: From Wagyu beef to bacon burgers, this is classy carnivory for the golden triangle set. Included in our list of Five Great Steak Frites in Paris.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Epicure (formerly Le Bristol)
properties.description: The gastronomic table at Le Bristol hotel has been renamed, but revered chef Eric Frechon remains at the stove. The dining room has been renovated, too, offering a view onto the hotel gardens. Three Michelin stars.
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: Garnier
properties.description: This posh brasserie near the Gare St. Lazare is one to remember when you’re craving oysters. Or sole, or daurade, or rougets. Included in our list of Five Great Places for Oysters.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: L’Atelier Etoile de Joël Robuchon
properties.description: Joël Robuchon’s empire expands again with the opening of another Atelier, this time on the Champs Elysées. This one is bigger than the left bank outpost, with an actual dining room in addition to the trademark counter seating.
properties.address: 133 avenue des Champs Elysées, 75008 (in the Publicis complex)
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: L’Instant d’Or
properties.description: What started as modern haute cuisine in the Golden Triangle has relaxed into a sort of posh neo-brasserie.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Tuesday-Saturday; closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: La Maison de l’Aubrac
properties.description: This classic off the Champs-Elysées is open 24 hours a day, serving up burgers, tartare, and aged steaks that will please carnivores.
properties.transport: George V (1) or Franklin D. Roosevelt (1, 9)
properties.hours: Open every day, 24 hours a day
properties.reservations: last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Lasserre
properties.description: If the walls at Lasserre could talk, they would tell stories about white doves, Marc Chagall, ortolan, and Audrey Hepburn, stories of glitterati and résistants taking their truffled macaroni under the retractable roof.
properties.hours: Dinner, Tuesday-Saturday; lunch, Thursday-Friday; closed Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Laurent
properties.description: Luxury and history come together at Laurent, where you can dine in the former hunting lodge of Louis XIV or, better yet, at a table in the garden. Fine dining, fine setting.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Lazare
properties.description: The bustling Saint-Lazare train station is home to this eagerly anticipated new restaurant from chef Eric Fréchon (L’Epicure and Mini Palais). Open seven days a week but requiring advance reservations and suffering, by many accounts, from atrocious service that undermines Fréchon’s delicious Norman-inflected cooking.
properties.address: In the front of Gare Saint-Lazare, rue Intérieure, 75008
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance
properties.address_clean: In the front of Gare Saint-Lazare, rue Intérieure, Paris 75008

properties.title: Le 39V
properties.description: A private elevator whisks you up to this rooftop address just off the Champs-Elysées, where chef Frederic Verdon (ex-Ducasse) is cooking in a sleek, black and chrome setting, with a small bar that offers a haven for solo diners, and a dining room that opens onto a leafy deck.
properties.address: 39 avenue George V, 75008 (entrance at 17 rue Quentin-Bauchart)
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Friday; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Le Cinq
properties.description: Haute cuisine in the George V hotel.
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: Le Griffonier
properties.description: A place to eat classic French bistro food (oeufs mayo, steak frites, celery remoulade), drink from an excellent wine list, and be surrounded (still, for now) by actual French people.
properties.hours: Closed for dinner every night except Thursday; open for lunch Monday-Friday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Mini Palais
properties.description: Eric Fréchon of the Bristol is the consulting chef of this contemporary, chic brasserie. Book a table on the terrace when weather permits. Open every day, all day.
properties.address: Ave. Winston Churchill, in The Grand Palais, 75008
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK
properties.address_clean: Ave. Winston Churchill, in The Grand Palais, Paris 75008

properties.title: Le Petit Chablisien
properties.description: This old-guard bistro near Gare Saint Lazare has recently been updated, with new décor and a new chef.
properties.hours: Monday-Friday, lunch and dinner; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Ledoyen
properties.description: This three-star restaurant is perched in a pavilion just off the Champs-Elysées and has been a dining destination since the French Revolution. Long-time chef Christian Le Squer handed the reigns to Yannick Alleno in July 2014, and Alleno has promised a renewed focus on what he considers to be the great strength of French cuisine – sauces. He is also, albeit more quietly than his rival Alain Ducasse, putting vegetables and peasant ingredients in the spotlight. Our meal featured low-cost ingredients like mackerel and butternut squash in starring roles, presented with both precision and imagination. A lunchtime tasting menu is priced at 128€ , and a ten course tasting menu at either lunch or dinner is 295€. -MZ in 2014
properties.hours: Closed Saturday, Sunday, and Monday lunch
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Les 110 de Taillevent
properties.description: Taillevent has reconceived  their second restaurant (formerly L’Angle du Faubourg) with a focus on wine pairings. There is a 44€ menu at lunch and dinner, but à la carte prices will put you in the 50-100€ range, before le vin.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Les Ambassadeurs (currently closed)
properties.description: CURRENTLY CLOSED UNTIL 2015. Pretend the financial crisis never happened, and book Les Ambassadeurs, where the young chef Christopher Hache is making a name for himself. One Michelin star.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday, Monday, and Saturday lunch
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: Napoleone
properties.description: The latest addition from Chef Christian Etchebest (from the Cantines de la Cigale, du Troquet & du Troquet Dupleix) is not perhaps his best, but it’s certainly better than most of what you’ll find along the Champs-Élysées. The neo-bistrot has a striking terrace, a beautiful Art Nouveau interior, a classic menu and is open late.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Neva Cuisine
properties.description: Contemporary French cooking in a polished, airy room from a couple of Grande Cascade alums.
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Okuda
properties.description: The first restaurant outside of Tokyo from chef Toru Okuda (of the Michelin-starred restaurants Okuda and Koju). Lunch for €180 and dinner for €250.

properties.title: Buvette
properties.description: Manhattanite Jody Williams has brought her well-loved French “gastrotheque” back to the city that inspired the original rustic-chic café. The appealing drinks menu includes artisanal cider, organic beer, a tight selection of wines, and pages of cocktail and apéritif options. Small plates range from 5-10€ and include plenty of vegetarian options (salads with fennel or beets, ratatouille, a croque with wild mushrooms and tangy cheese) alongside satisfying miniature versions of coq au vin, os à moelle, and hachis parmentier. Service is kind, the design is familiar but beautiful – all in all a great addition to the already booming neighborhood south of Pigalle.
properties.hours: Closed Monday; Open all day Tuesday-Sunday
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted
properties.style: Small plates & tapas, classic French, American

properties.title: Caillebotte

properties.hours: Closed Saturday and Sunday; Open Monday-Friday for lunch and dinner

properties.title: Chartier

properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: La Maison Mère

properties.title: La Régalade Conservatoire
properties.description: Chef Bruno Doucet took over La Régalade from his boss Yves Camdeborde in 2004, then added La Régalade Saint Honoré in 2010. This third location, part of a new boutique hotel designed by Jean-Michel Wilmotte, opened in February 2013 and is serving classic Doucet bistro fare like house-made terrine, pork belly with lentils, sea bream with fennel, rice pudding, and a Grand Marnier soufflé. Affordably priced with prix-fixe menus at lunch (26€) and dinner (35€).
properties.hours: Closed Saturday lunch and all day Sunday
properties.reservations: Last-minute ok (this may change)

properties.title: La Terrasse

The southern background of owner Nicolas Lacaze shines in seafood dishes like cod with Niçoise vegetables or tiny sweet mussels marinière. properties.title: The Sunken Chip
properties.description: Michael Greenwold of Roseval and James Whelan of L’Inconnu have teamed up to open the first dedicated fish and chips shop in Paris. Hake, pollock or catch of the day are available alongside thick chips and mushy peas. Pickled eggs, fish nuggets, chip butties (french fry sandwiches) and candies from across the chunnel make for an authentic Brit experience.

properties.title: Urfa Dürüm
properties.description: No ordinary kebab joint,the bread at this Kurdish sandwich shop is made before your eyes, split and filled with lamb, beef, or chicken that’s been grilled to order, garnished simply with a few greens, red onion, sliced tomato and herbs.

properties.title: Vivant Table
properties.description: Pierre Jancou has relaunched Vivant Table with chef Sota (ex-Troisgros, Robuchon, Stella Maris & Toyo) at the helm and more ambitious menus at 29/39€ at lunch and 55€ at dinner. There’s also a carte blanch menu with 7-8 dishes (no choice). The wine remains all-natural, but the cooking is better than ever. Update: Jancou sold Vivant Table and Vivant Cave in December 2013 to the owners of Racines.

properties.description: Subtle, inexpensive Japanese bites from a former chef at Abri. Small plates in a small place with a nice list of natural wines. There are only 14 seats so be prepared to queue.

properties.title: A La Renaissance

properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Astier

properties.description: Small plates range from the standard charcuterie and now-obligatory burrata to more light and creative fare, based on great products from the likes of Terroirs d’Avenir and Joël Thiébault. The vibe is relaxed, the prices are right, and the wines are natural. Note: James Henry, the chef mentioned in most of these reviews, has left and is now at Bones.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Aux Deux Amis

properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Bistrot Paul Bert

properties.title: Blue Valentine
