properties.reservations: Book a couple days in advance
properties.address_clean: 13 rue de la Pierre Levée, Paris 75011

properties.title: Bones
properties.description: After making a name for himself at Au Passage, Aussie chef James Henry is back with an ambitious restaurant. Its name is reflected in Henry’s attention to raw materials – stripped-down brick and stone in the dining room, and pristine products in the kitchen. Ingredients that Henry doesn’t make himself (bread, butter, fresh cheese and charcuterie) are carefully sourced from Annie Bertin, Terroirs d’Avenir, La Ruchotte, and other reputable producers. Preparations might be raw, pickled, smoked, barbecued or frozen, but the integrity of the base ingredient still shines through. The no-choice tasting menu includes four courses plus amuses for 47€. Add another 8€ for cheese. Up front, there’s a bar serving craft beers and wines by the glass, along with oysters, raw fish sliced to order, and house-made charcuterie. Expect loud music and plenty of youthful eastern Paris attitude. Named as one of our favorite new restaurants of 2013.
properties.hours: Dinner Tuesday through Saturday; Closed Sunday and Monday.
properties.reservations: Book a few weeks in advance (no reservations for bar)

properties.title: Caffé dei Cioppi
properties.description: Almost universally adored, this tiny spot, hidden from the street, is the Italian restaurant everyone wishes were in their neighborhood. Booking imperative.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Tuesday-Friday; available for private parties on Saturdays and Mondays
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance
properties.address_clean: 159 rue du Faubourg St. Antoine, Paris 75011

properties.title: CheZaline
properties.description: Delphine Zampetti, recently of Le Verre Volé, has opened this bright spot, serving sandwiches, salads, and plats du jour for under 10€, to stay or to go. Natural wines, too.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Clamato
properties.description: A seafood and shellfish-centric joint from Bertrand Grébaut of Septime. Expect small plates of pristine marinated fish, platters of oysters, silky crab fritters (accrabes) and maple syrup pie for dessert. Wines are natural and well-selected, just like at Septime. One of our favorite new restaurants of 2013.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Clown Bar
properties.description: No clowning around here. A serious team from Saturne has taken over the historic bar near Cirque d’Hiver. The beautiful Belle Epoque space remains (tastefully) decorated with clowns, but the menu has been revived by Sota Atsumi’s intriguing product focused small plates. Wines are natural, with good options by the glass as well as the bottle.
properties.hours: Closed Monday & Tuesday; Open for breakfast, lunch and dinner Wednesday-Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a couple days in advance

properties.title: Come A Casa
properties.description: A tiny gem of a restaurant with an even tinier menu that changes each day. The warm welcome and trilingual service is Italian hospitality at its finest. The wine list is short, affordable, and Italian.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday, Open Monday from 7pm-10pm and Tuesday-Saturday 12pm-2
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Deux Fois Plus de Piment
properties.description: The place for pepper-laden Chinese fare.
properties.hours: Dinner, every day; Lunch on Thurday, Saturday, Monday, and Tuesday
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Freddie’s Deli
properties.description: Kristin Frederick (of the food truck Le Camion qui Fume) has opened up a stationary restaurant serving hot American style sandwiches. Hoagie and hamburger buns from Gontran Cherrier are stuffed with eggplant parmesan, Philly-style cheesesteaks, pork carnitas with guacamole, turkey with bacon, cheese and chipotle sauce, tuna steak with aioli and chipotle, roast beef covered in grilled onions and horseradish, or steak with chimichurri sauce. We’d be remiss not to mention the pastrami cured in-house for 7-10 days and served either on rye with mustard or in a hefty Reuben. Leave room for over the top oreo and lemon meringue pies, or a David Lebovitz approved brownie. There’s even a hand washing sink for the inevitable mess you will make
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Jeanne A
properties.description: This eat-in epicerie and wine shop from the owners of the classic Astier offers classic comfort food, to stay or to go, at reasonable prices.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: L’Auberge Flora
properties.description: Flora herself does the cooking at this urban inn, offering a range of shareable small plates, or a heftier menu (at higher prices).
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: L’Ecailler du Bistrot
properties.description: The “bistrot” in question is carnivore-heaven Paul Bert, just next door. But at L’Ecailler the focus is on seafood, including a gorgeous array of Belon, Utah Beach, and Spéciales. Included in our editors’ list of Five Great places for oysters.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: La Pulperia
properties.description: This Argentinian restaurant from Fernando de Tomaso could more accurately be called a bifteckeria, given the number and size of steak offerings on their menu. Expect giant portions, plenty of delicious chimichurri, and a good list (mostly French, surprisingly) wines.
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Le 6 Paul Bert
properties.description: This spot from Bertrand Auboyneau is just a few doors down from his Bistrot Paul Bert, but it’s a world apart in terms of cuisine. The emphasis on good product remains, but Le 6 finds chef Louis-Philippe composing small and modern plates (shaved vegetables, raw and marinated proteins, creative use of dairy) that have more in common with Le Dauphin and Au Passage than a classic Paris bistro. While the wine list is outstanding, and the small plates range in price from only €8-14, don’t mistake this for a drop-in wine bar. It feels like a restaurant, complete with a menu option, and the expected popularity will oblige you to book.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday night plus all day Sunday and Monday. Open Saturday until 8pm for epicerie only (charcuterie, sandwiches).
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Le Chardenoux
properties.description: Celebrity chef Cyril Lignac took over this historic bistro in 2008.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Le Chateaubriand
properties.description: You can only reserve for the first seating at Le Chateaubriand. After that, you’ll have to wait in line with everyone else for a stab at Iñaki Aizpitarte’s unique menu, a parade of forgotten vegetables, fish, and meat (some raw, some cooked) that landed the restaurant on San Pellegrino’s 50 Best list last year.
properties.hours: Dinner only, Closed Sunday, Closed Monday
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: Le Dauphin
properties.description: This wine bar next door to (and run by) Le Chateaubriand boasts food by Inaki Aizpitarte, a smooth marble design by Rem Koolhaas and Clement Blanchet, and a great selection of affordable vins naturels.
properties.hours: Dinner, Tuesday-Saturday; lunch, Tuesday-Friday; Closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Le Perchoir
properties.description: The sunset over Sacré-Coeur is hard to beat from this perch. Queue early for drinks and bar snacks on the stellar roof deck with a stand-out 360° view of Paris (and packs of hipsters). Or, alternately, avoid the lines by booking a reservation for a prix-fixe dinner in the restaurant below. Chef Benoît Dumas’ Provencal menu is served family-style.
properties.hours: Restaurant open Wednesday-Sunday; closed Monday and Tuesday; Bar open Tuesday-Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few weeks in advance

properties.title: Le Repaire de Cartouche
properties.description: Chef Rodolphe Paquin continues to gets high marks for simple, hearty food and massive wine list. In May 2014, he transformed the lower dining room (entrance on rue Amelot) into a wine bar specializing in terrines and small plates to accompany.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance
properties.address_clean: 8 boulevard des Filles du Calvaire, Paris 75011

properties.title: Le Servan
properties.description: Tatiana Levha, formerly at L’Arpège and L’Astrance, and her sister Katia have opened up this light, airy bistro with a central bar & hand painted ceiling. The short list of offerings changes each day, but expect seasonally driven cuisine inflected with international touches like tandoori spiced beurre blanc atop asparagus or harissa to spice up the line caught hake. Dessert left room for improvement, but otherwise Le Servan had reasonably priced, expertly executed dishes and friendly service in a beautiful space.
properties.transport: Rue Saint Maur (3), Père Lachaise (2,3), Voltaire (9)

properties.title: Le Sot-l’y-Laisse
properties.description: This longstanding neighborhood bistro has a new lease on life thanks to Eiji Doihara, a Japanese chef with a classical French resumé.
properties.hours: Dinner, Monday-Saturday; lunch, Tuesday-Friday; closed Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Les Déserteurs
properties.description: Daniel Baratier and Alexandre Céret have deserted Le Sergent Recruteur where they were the chef and sommelier respectively, and created their own modern, product-focused bistro in the space that used to be Giovanni Passerini’s Rino.
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Pizza dei Cioppi
properties.description: The much adored and hard to book Caffé dei Cioppi has branched out into pizza with pleasing results. The long, rectangular pizza al taglio with a springy foccacia base is available by the slice for roughly 6.50€. Offerings include pizzas like the Calabrese (spicy N’duja sausage spread, dollops of sheep’s milk ricotta, mozzarella and tomato sauce), Focaccia farcie (cherry tomatoes, fresh buffalo mozzarella and an unruly mound of arugula) or the Vegetariana (sheep’s milk ricotta, eggplant, roasted red peppers and mozzarella), alongside some salads and a handful of desserts. There’s Birra del Borgo to wash it all down. You can eat onsite at one of the few Formica tables, but you can also get your giant slice to go, too.
properties.reservations: Not accepted

properties.title: Qui Plume la Lune
properties.description: Qui Plume la Lune is the showcase for chef Jackie Ribault’s unique brand of Franco-Japanese cooking.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Restaurant Pierre Sang Boyer
properties.description: After a series of pop-ups, Top Chef finalist Pierre Sang Boyer has an address in Oberkampf, an open-kitchen showcase for his colorful, modern cooking.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Tuesday-Friday; dinner only on Saturday; closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: not accepted

properties.title: Retro’Bottega
properties.description: This little Italian épicerie-à-manger has just a handful of tables and plenty of heart. Plan to eat simple and product-driven fare and to drink whatever Pietro recommends.
properties.hours: Tuesday-Saturday, 10 a.m.-11 p.m.; closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Last minute reservations usually ok

properties.title: Sassotondo
properties.description: A Tuscan address from Frederic Hubig of Astier and Jeanne A.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Septime
properties.description: Book well in advance, and then look forward to Bertrand Grébaut’s  beautiful, seasonal cooking, pristine ingredients, and a fine list of natural wines to match.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Soya
properties.description: The vegetarian landscape in Paris continues to improve. In the airy, minimally decorated dining room at Soya, you’ll find the usual suspects (salads, curries, savory tarts, soy in all its forms), all organic, and a thoughtful winelist.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK
properties.address_clean: 20 rue de la Pierre Levée, Paris 75011

properties.title: The Green Goose
properties.description: An Irish pub that’s actually good with unusual craft beers (no Guinness), Scotch eggs, a fair burger, and a big Sunday brunch.
properties.reservations: Walk-Ins Welcome

properties.title: West Country Girl
properties.description: The fact that it’s named for a Nick Cave song hints that this is a crêperie that’s cooler than most. Cool? Yes. And tasty.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday night (open Sunday brunch) and all day Monday
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Yard
properties.description: The former construction yard turned bistro has been around Père Lachaise for years, but the arrival of chefs Shaun Kelly and Eleni Sapera, formerly of Au Passage and Bones, is a breath of fresh air. Expect a lengthy list of natural wines, modern product driven small plates, and a warm welcome from owner Jane Drotter.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday & Sunday; Open for lunch & dinner Tuesday-Friday; Lunch only on Monday
properties.reservations: No reservations accepted for lunch, Book a few days in advance for dinner

properties.title: A la Biche au Bois
properties.description: You’ll find hearty cocottes at this neighborhood favorite, accompanied by piles of purée or frites. Finish with ripe cheese and a gigantic ile flottante, and then roll home.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday and Sunday; closed Monday lunch.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Café Cartouche
properties.description: This is the second address from Rodolphe Paquin of Le Repaire de Cartouche.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: La Gazzetta
properties.description: Petter Nilsson’s inspired, eclectic cooking drew rave reviews. Then he left, came back, and now he’s flown the coop again for Sweden. We’ll see?
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Le Baron Rouge
properties.description: Join the rest of the neighborhood here on Sunday afternoons for a post-market glass of wine (direct from the barrel), a plate of cheese or charcuterie or, in winter, a dozen oysters. Bottles to go, too.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Shan Goût
properties.description: This tiny, highly regarded Chinese restaurant veers from the usual family style format, offering a limited-choice, three-course menu.
properties.transport: Gare de Lyon (1, 14; RER A, D)
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Table
properties.description: We stayed away from Table for quite some time, fearing that it would be terrible. With a food writer (Bruno Verjus) in the kitchen and seemingly unlimited funds for decor and product sourcing from the guy that founded L’Occitane, it seemed like the sort of place that would be long on concept, high on prices, and short on soul. In recent months, however, we’ve become devoted fans of the 3-course lunch for 25€. Prices are much higher at dinner, but the lunch is one of the best deals in town. – MZ in 2014
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Will
properties.description: This is the first restaurant for globe trotting chef William Pradeleix who has worked in London under Hélène Darroze, in Bora Bora with Jean-Georges Vongerichten, and most recently, headed up the kitchen at Manger. His precise, Asian-inflected cuisine is drawing diners to the Aligre market area.
properties.reservations: Last minute bookings usually okay

properties.title: Au Petit Marguery
properties.description: A delightfully unmodernized table, especially good in game season, when you’ll find roast partridge, grouse, wild duck, and lièvre à la royale. Finish with the Grand Marnier soufflé.
properties.hours: Monday-Saturday, lunch and dinner; Sunday, dinner only.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Les Delices de Shandong
properties.description: A well-regarded Chinese table, run by a Qingdao native, specializing in the cuisine of the Shandong province, in eastern China.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Thursday-Tuesday; closed Wednesday
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Green Pizz
properties.description: When only organic and environmentally responsible vegetarian pizza delivered on a skateboard or electric scooter will do, there’s Green Pizz.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Tuesday-Saturday; closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: L’Auberge du 15
properties.description: Chef Nicolas Castelet might be young, but he’s serving up plenty of nostalgia on his classic menu.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: L’Auberge du Roi Gradlon
properties.description: Hearty yet refined Breton cooking in an upscale setting from Nicolas Castelet, the chef behind L’Auberge du 15.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: L’Avant Gout
properties.description: Christophe Beaufront’s neo-bistro has been a stronghold of the Buttes aux Cailles neighborhood since opening more than ten years ago.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: L’Ourcine
properties.description: The well-liked bistro is back after a renovation. Chef Sylvain Danière uses stellar producers and serves classic, unpretentious food at fair prices.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday and Monday; open Tuesday-Saturday for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Lao Lane Xang 2
properties.description: A much-loved address for Laotian, Vietnamese, and Thai specialties.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Likafo
properties.description: A favorite for authentic Cantonese cooking.
properties.transport: Maison Blanche or Porte de Choisy (7)
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted except for parties of 8 or more

properties.title: Nüba
properties.description: Probably the best nightclub food in all of Paris. Japanese, Swedish and French fusion (in bento box form) from chef Alexandre Morin formerly of Ze Kitchen Galerie and Le Galopin. The décor is somewhat sterile, but it barely matters when the backdrop is a waterfront view from the rooftop of Les Docks.
properties.transport: Gare d’Austerlitz (5, 10, RER C), Quai de la Gare (6)
properties.hours: Closed Monday; Open Tuesday-Saturday 12pm-3pm and 7pm-11pm and Sunday 12pm-5pm
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Pho 14
properties.description: It’s easy to find Pho 14. Just look for the line. Open every day from 9 a.m. to 11 p.m.
properties.reservations: reservations not accepted

properties.title: Simone
properties.description: An inventive neo-bistro with open kitchen, outdoor terrace, and well-priced, exclusively natural wines from their neighboring cave à vin.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday & Monday; Open Tuesday-Saturday for lunch & dinner

properties.title: Tricotin
properties.description: A bustling Chinese canteen, known especially for dim sum.
properties.reservations: reservations not necessary

properties.title: Crêperie Josselin
properties.description: The city’s most buttery, authentic crêpes served in an old-school dining room full of dark wood and Breton lace.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Jeu de Quilles
properties.description: Benoit Reix packs them into his tiny, bright bistro, watching from behind the counter as diners happily devour dishes from his small, always-changing menu. Meats come from next-door-neighbor Hugo Desnoyer, and the wines are natural.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: L’Assiette
properties.description: French bistro food, expertly executed by chef David Rathgeber. Classics like cassoulet, tête de veau and escargot, created with fresh ingredients for local clients. That’s a rarity in Paris, these days.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: La Cantine du Troquet
properties.description: Arrive early (doors open at 7pm) to avoid a wait at this casual, no-reservations bistro run by chef Christian Etchebest.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: La Cerisaie
properties.description: Closet-sized La Cerisaie serves southwestern cuisine. Foie gras abounds.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: La Régalade
properties.description: You can’t talk about “la bistronomie” without mentioning La Régalade.
properties.hours: Monday, dinner only; Tuesday-Friday, lunch and dinner; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Le Bistrot du Dôme
properties.description: The smaller sibling of the grand brasserie Le Dôme, just around the corner.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually O.K.

properties.title: Le Cornichon
properties.description: Here you’ll find robust, seasonal bistro cooking from a Chez l’Ami Jean alum. Menus at 31€/34€ for lunch/dinner, unless you spring for the Desnoyer côte de veau, seasonal game dishes, or other items that carry a supplement.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually O.K.

properties.title: Le Dôme
properties.description: Le Dôme, with its sparkling platters of fruits de mer, remains an address for power lunches and tourists looking to rub shoulders with Hemingway’s ghost while getting their fill of zinc and iodine.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Le Severo
properties.description: Meat lovers, meet Le Severo, where former butcher William Bernet offers a legendary tartare, honest-to-goodness aged steaks (surprisingly rare in Paris), fat frites, and a great wine list. Included in our list of Five Great Steak Frites in Paris.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Axuria
properties.description: A contemporary gastro-bistro, with an emphasis on fish. Open every day.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Ciel de Paris
properties.description: Recently reopened with a sleek new design, a table at this resto on the 56th floor of the Tour Montparnasse affords sweeping views over Paris.
properties.address: 33 avenue du Maine (in the tour Montparnasse), 75015
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Jadis
properties.description: Forgotten dishes are given new life at Jadis, where old recipes meet technical rigor and today’s best ingredients.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance
properties.address_clean: 208 rue de la Croix Nivert, Paris 75015

properties.title: La Cabane à Huitres
properties.description: Francis Dubourg grows his oysters in the Arcachon basin and brings them direct to Paris for tasting in this adorable room outfitted to feel like a seaside shack (cabane).
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: La Cantine du Troquet Dupleix
properties.description: Lusty Basque fare, affordably priced. Arrive early (doors open at 7pm) to avoid a wait at this casual, no-reservations bistro run by chef Christian Etchebest.
properties.hours: Open every day for dinner only
properties.reservations: Not accepted

properties.title: Le Casse Noix
properties.description: Le Casse Noix is helmed by Pierre-Olivier Lenormand, who spent six years at La Régalade. With its old-timey decor and generous cooking (think braised beef cheeks and ile flottante), you can add it to the 15th’s already lengthy roster of solid bistros.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: L’Epicuriste
properties.description: Like a couple who has decided to have kids, the former owners of L’Epigramme have moved to a larger space in the 15th, serving the same generous bistro cooking that brought them notice back in the 6th.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Le Grand Pan
properties.description: Benoit Gauthier’s Le Grand Pan unfussily and deliciously serves up superb meats and market-fresh vegetables.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Le Marcab
properties.description: The room feels posh, but the prices are reasonable at Le Marcab. Open every day.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Le Pario
properties.description: Modern French food from Brazilian chef Eduardo Jacinto, who trained under Christian Constant at Le Violin d’Ingres. Fejoiada, the hearty Brazilian bean stew, is available every Saturday at lunch.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday; Open Monday-Saturday for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Les Trois Garçons
properties.description: A neighborhood neo-retro bistro. The large, shady terrasse facing a quiet square makes up for the lackadaisical service and makes this a local favorite for outdoor dining.
properties.reservations: Reservations not required

properties.title: L’Os à Moelle
properties.description: After working for Christian Constant (along with Yves Camdeborde, Thierry Breton and Rodolpe Paquin), Thierry Faucher made a name for himself more than a decade ago at this casual bistro years. He sold it in 2011 to Stéphane Schmidt, then bought it back in 2014.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Tuesday-Saturday; closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Ty Breiz
properties.description: This Montparnasse crêperie ranked #2 in Figaroscopes 2009 survey of the best galettes complètes in Paris, and made the cut for our list of Five Great for Crêpes. Continuous, all-day service.
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Akrame
properties.description: After leaving his post at the rococo, subterranean Konfidential, Gagnaire- and Adria-alum Akrame Benallal resurfaced with this eponymous restaurant in the 16th, serving globally-influenced cooking in a no-choice menu format.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Chez Géraud
properties.description: Classic, unfussy comfort food from Ducasse alum Gabriel Grapin at this warm and inviting bistro in an old and moneyed part of town.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday lunch, and all day Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Étude
properties.description: Precise and elegant Franco-Japanese fusion food in a zen setting.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday and Monday; Open Tuesday-Friday for dinner and Thursday-Friday for lunch
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance
properties.address_clean: 14 rue du Bouquet de Longchamp, Paris 75016

properties.title: L’Abeille
properties.description: Housed in in the Shangri-La hotel, this addition to Paris’ haute dining scene set critics abuzz.
properties.hours: Dinner only, Tuesday through Saturday; closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: L’Astrance
properties.description: Pascal Barbot continues to impress diners (those who manage to get a reservation) with a culinary high wire act that is both grounded and innovative, French and global, serious and playful. To wit, his signature dish: A galette of thinly sliced, raw champignons de Paris and verjus-marinated foie gras (also raw), with hazelnut oil and lemon confit.
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: La Grande Cascade
properties.description: This Michelin one-star is in a grand pavilion in the Bois de Boulogne.
properties.address: Allée de Longchamp – in the Bois de Boulogne, 75016
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance
properties.address_clean: Allée de Longchamp – in the Bois de Boulogne, Paris 75016

properties.title: Les Tablettes
properties.description: In the old La Table de Joël Robuchon location, Les Tablettes reopened with a new chef (Jean-Louis Nomicos) and a pop attitude.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: LiLi
properties.description: Haute Cantonese cuisine in a luxe setting at the recently opened Hotel Peninsula Paris. Former Top Chef contestant Jean-Edern Hurstel is almost exclusively using high quality French ingredients.
properties.reservations: Book a few weeks in advance

properties.title: Mets Gusto
properties.description: A contemporary Mediterranean bistro in the 16th.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday, Monday, and Saturday lunch
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Shang Palace
properties.description: Haute Cantonese cooking comes to Paris.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Agapé Bis
properties.description: An upmarket bistro from the team behind Agapé and Agapé substance. A new chef arrived in May of 2011.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Atao
properties.description: Oysters and a wide array of fruits de mer, in an airy blue and white room that will take you from Batignolles to the Brittany coast.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Coretta
properties.description: A trio of restaurateurs including Beatriz Gonzalez and Matthieu Marcant of Neva and chef Jean-François Pataleon of L’Affable have combined forces at this minimalist and modern French restaurant overlooking the Parc Martin Luther King.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday lunch; Open lunch and dinner Monday-Saturday and dinner Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Frédéric Simonin
properties.description: Precise, direct cooking in a luxe, insulated room, this was one of the most talked about openings of Spring 2010.
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance

properties.title: Guy Savoy
properties.description: Guy Savoy’s excellent service and reliably fine food have fostered a loyal local and international clientele. Note: Savoy will soon be relocating the the Left Bank.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday, Closed Monday, Closed Saturday lunch
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: L’Entredgeu
properties.description: This beloved Basque bistro is usually packed with locals.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Tuesday-Saturday; closed Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: L’Huitrier
properties.description: Claires and Belons are on the menu at this sleek address in the 17th, included in our list of Five Great Places for Oysters.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: La Fourchette du Printemps
properties.description: The setting is no-frills but the food is refined at this small bistro on the edge of the 17th, which earned one Michelin star in 2011.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Friday; Saturday, dinner only; closed Sunday
properties.reservations: book a few days in advance

properties.title: Le Bouchon et L’Assiette
properties.description: Le Bouchon et L’Assiette offers more proof that there’s plenty of good cooking to be found outside the city center.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Le Crabe Marteau
properties.description: Pretend you’re in Brest as you hammer away at fresh crab, oysters, and other shellfish at this seafood shack in the 17th.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Saturday; closed Sunday
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Le Dodin
properties.description: Upscale bistro cooking from longtime American-in-Paris Mark Singer.
properties.hours: Tuesday-Friday, lunch and dinner; Saturday, dinner only
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: L’Envie du Jour
properties.description: A new team has renovated the space that used to be Bigarrade and are turning out fresh, seasonal produce before your eyes in a wide open kitchen.
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance

properties.title: Les Fougères
properties.description: Offering modern French cooking in a lovely 30-seat dining room, Les Fougeres manages to be elegant without being stuffy.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Rech
properties.description: This seafood restaurant Rech, around since 1925, is now part of the Alain Ducasse bistro collection.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Roca
properties.description: A highly praised neo-bistro from Le Richer alum Alexandre Giesbert who presents fresh products creatively with a slightly international bent.
properties.hours: Closed Saturday and Sunday; Open Monday-Friday for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Au Clocher de Montmartre
properties.description: An easy-going, all-day spot from Antoine Heerah.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Bob’s Bake Shop
properties.description: Bob (aka Marc Grossman)’s mini empire continues to expand with this American style diner and bakery complete with pecan, lattice-topped cherry or rhubarb pies, Belleville Brulerie coffee, hand-rolled bagels and even their elusive brethren, bialys. There’s a pretty lovely outdoor terrasse, too and wifi.
properties.address: Halle Pajol, 12 esplanade Nathalie Sarraute (across from 39 rue Pajol), 75018
properties.hours: Open every day for breakfast & lunch (evening hours expected soon)
properties.reservations: Walk-ins Welcome
properties.address_clean: Halle Pajol, 12 esplanade Nathalie Sarraute , Paris 75018

properties.title: Bululu Arepera
properties.description: Essentially just a take-out counter and four tables, Bululu has a vegetarian-friendly menu of handmade arepas (gluten-free corn pancakes) stuffed with avocado, Venezuelan cheeses, plantains, beans or meat. Wash them down with Venezuelan rum-based tropical cocktails served in mason jars. Très Brooklyn in Montmartre.
properties.address: 20 rue de la Fontaine du But, 75018
properties.reservations: Book a day or two in advance
properties.address_clean: 20 rue de la Fontaine du But, Paris 75018

properties.title: Café Burq
properties.description: This funky Montmartre bistro is open late.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday; Open dinner, Monday-Saturday; lunch, Tuesday-Friday only
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Chamarré Montmartre
properties.description: Chef Antoine Heerah draws from the flavors and ingredients of his native Mauritius — and all around the Indian ocean — and fuses them with French technique.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Chéri Bibi
properties.description: An arty haven on the east side of Sacre-Coeur. Flea-market decor, traditional French cooking and easy prices.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Guilo Guilo
properties.description: Reserve well in advance for a seat at the counter where you can watch Kyoto chef Eichi Edakuni prepare a modern Japanese feast before your eyes.
properties.hours: Open for dinner only, on varying days. Call for info.
properties.reservations: Book many weeks in advance

properties.title: Il Brigante
properties.description: The kitchen and dining room are one and the same at Il Brigante where a Calabrian pizzaiolo is turning out masterful cracker-crusted pizzas. Try the Carboneri with a runny egg, bufala mozzarella, pecorino and a sprinkling of black pepper. Pizzas available to go, too.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday; Open Monday-Saturday for lunch and dinner
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Jeanne B
properties.description: A cheerful clone of Jeanne A for the underserved Montmartre neighborhood – this casual eatery and take-out epicerie is open seven days a week with continuous service.
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: La Table d’Eugène
properties.description: Chef Geoffroy Maillard spent five years working under Eric Frechon at the Bristol before opening a place of his own in a gastronomically under-served part of the 18th.
properties.reservations: Reserve a few days in advance

properties.title: La Rallonge
properties.description: A casual wine bar from Chef Geoffroy Maillard serving Spanish-ish small plates, just down the street from La Table d’Eugene. Don’t miss the risotto–elbow noodles with a creamy truffled mushroom sauce and served in a tiny Staub casserole.
properties.hours: Closed Sunday; Open Monday-Saturday for dinner
properties.reservations: Reservations not required

properties.title: Le Bal Café
properties.description: At this café/exhibition space on a quiet impasse near Place de Clichy, a pair of former Rose Bakery cooks are giving modern British cooking a very good name (particularly for brunch) and a serious barista is serving some of the best coffee in town.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: La Cantine de la Cigale
properties.description: Warm, welcoming and well-priced. The new bistro from Christian Etchebest follows the model of his other cantines, La Cantine du Troquet and La Cantine du Troquet Dupleix; this time, in association with the concert venue La Cigale.
properties.hours: Closed Sundays; Open lunch and dinner Mondays-Saturdays
properties.reservations: Reservations not accepted

properties.title: Le Coq Rico
properties.description: It’s all about the bird at Le Coq Rico.
properties.reservations: Last minute usually OK

properties.title: Le Grand 8
properties.description: Natural wines and simple cooking rule at this low-key Montmartre bistro.
properties.hours: Closed Monday; Dinner, Tuesday-Sunday; lunch, Saturday-Sunday
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Le Petit Trianon
properties.description: The menu at Le Petit Trianon is typical café and brasserie fare: Croques monsieur et madame, salads, and tartines. Open 8 a.m. to 2 a.m. every day, continuously.
properties.reservations: Reservations not necessary

properties.title: Marcel
properties.description: Another brunch spot with an Anglo accent, in this case both British (porridge, scones, an English breakfast) and American (fluffy blueberry pancakes, a BLT).
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Miroir
properties.description: A neighborhood bistro in the heart of tourist-ville.
properties.hours: Tuesday-Saturday, lunch and dinner; Sunday, lunch only; closed Monday
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Au Boeuf Couronné
properties.description: Meat is king at Au Boeuf Couronné, a restaurant across the street from the Parc de la Villette (previous site of the Paris slaughterhouse). It’s a beautiful old brasserie and a reliable place (open every day) for steak lovers in search of a slab.
properties.hours: Open every day (including Sunday and Monday)
properties.reservations: Last minute booking usually OK

properties.title: Le Chapeau Melon
properties.description: The “bowler hat” began as a wine shop featuring the astute organic selections of Olivier Camus (the former husband/co-owner of Raquel Carena/Le Baratin). Soon after, this caviste began serving dinner to a lucky few on Tuesday though Friday nights. His prix-fixe includes four incredible no-choice courses for less than €30. The selection of bottles that line the walls makes this a delight for any wine lover, and the cooking remains a steal for the price.
properties.hours: Dinner, Wednesday-Sunday; shop, Tuesday-Saturday, 11am-1pm and 4pm-8pm; closed Monday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Ô Divin
properties.description: What started off as a small natural wine bar near the Parc des Buttes Chaumont became in 2013, with the recruitment of chef Mathieu Moity, a more ambitious restaurant serving a Modern French tasting menu on Tuesday-Friday nights. Saturday night reverts to the old wine bar formula – excellent cheese and charcuterie plus oysters and other simple fare. Monday nights are exceptionally fun when the kitchen serves nothing but couscous de porc – an untraditional version with crispy suckling pig and vegetables that haven’t been simmered into oblivion. Owner and natural wine lover Naoufel Zaïm maintains a lengthy list of interesting bottles, but he’ll also pour glass by glass to let you discover new wines. The dining room is tiny, but in nice weather the doors open onto an interior courtyard that makes for one of Paris’ most charming outdoor patios. A local and friendly vibe, thanks to the out-of-the-way location.
properties.hours: Open Monday-Saturday for dinner and Tuesdays-Fridays for lunch; Closed Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Quedubon
properties.description: You can call Quedubon a bistro or a wine bar or a cave. All apply to this address near the beautiful Parc des Buttes Chaumont. The simple food ranges from light (capriccios of fresh fish) to homey (braised meats) to downright offal (veal brains), and is washed down by one of the vins naturels that populate the impressive wine list maintained by Gilles Bénard. Owing in part to the non-central location, there’s a village-like feeling to this friendly place.
properties.hours: Open Tuesday-Friday for lunch & dinner, plus Saturday dinner. Closed for lunch on Saturday and all day Sunday & Monday.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Chatomat
properties.description: Light and bright, based on pedigreed produce, the cooking at this Ménilmontant is firmly of the moment. So, too, is the exposed brick and industrial lighting in the small dining room. One of the few Modern French tables that offers a choice for every course, rather than a tasting menu.
properties.hours: Dinner only Tuesday-Saturday plus the first Sunday of every month. Closed Monday and most Sundays.
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Le Baratin
properties.description: Food and wine pilgrims are willing to climb the hill for this Belleville institution. Raquel Carena tends the fire, offering her own brand of bistro cooking, sometimes delicate, sometimes hearty, always heartfelt. Her husband Philippe’s wine cellar is one of the best in town, with an emphasis on small independent producers and natural wines. Don’t expect a smile from him, or really anyone else working there, just be glad that this place exists. The lunch menu remains one of the best deals in town.
properties.hours: Closed for lunch on Saturday and all day Sunday and Monday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance

properties.title: Roseval
properties.description: Young chefs Michael Greenwold and Simone Tondo worked previously at Le Chateaubriand and Rino, and the influence of those kitchens can be felt at their joint venture in Ménilmontant. Modern French  cooking, like this take on beef tartare with horseradish granita (photo above), can be found throughout the no-choice menu for 40€. Consider springing for the wine pairings (77€ total) – there’s a very interesting wine list with an emphasis on les naturels from sommelière Ericka Biswell. There’s an insider (but not exclusive) feeling here in the bare bones dining room that’s enlivened by a very fashionable young clientele in a corner of Paris ignored by most tourists.  NOTE: As of September 2014, Michael Greenwold has left the restaurant.
properties.reservations: Book a week in advance

properties.title: Ferme Yamashita
properties.description: To sample Asafumi Yamashita’s pampered produce, you can either book a three-star table (L’Astrance, Pierre Gagnaire) or head directly to the source. After a tour of the vegetable patch, guests at this communal table in the countryside sit down to share 6-10 small plates. Weekends only.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner on Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a week or two in advance
properties.address_clean: Chemin des Trois Poiriers, Paris 78130 Chapet

properties.title: MaSa
properties.description: MaSa is short for “manipulateur de saveurs,” and the manipulator in this case is chef Hervé Rodriguez, who is serving modern, cerebral fare at this spot in Boulogne-Billancourt.
properties.hours: Lunch and dinner, Monday-Friday; closed Saturday and Sunday
properties.reservations: Book a few days in advance
